cluster_relations.rel_desc: Protecting bird populations helps ensure the health of ecosystems.

qualifiers.OperationalConstraint: when bird populations and habitats are protected
qualifiers.ConditionExpression: if bird populations and their habitats are protected

remarks: Protection aspect encoded as a condition on the relation.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Protecting bird habitats supports the health of ecosystems.

qualifiers.OperationalConstraint: when habitats are protected (with bird populations)
qualifiers.ConditionExpression: if bird populations and their habitats are protected

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Protecting bird populations contributes to the resilience of ecosystems.

qualifiers.OperationalConstraint: when bird populations and habitats are protected
qualifiers.ConditionExpression: if bird populations and their habitats are protected

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Protecting bird habitats contributes to ecosystem resilience.

qualifiers.OperationalConstraint: when habitats are protected (with bird populations)
qualifiers.ConditionExpression: if bird populations and their habitats are protected

args.canonical_rel_desc: The subject contributes positively to the health, resilience, or overall condition of ecosystems.
args.justification: All four relations describe how protecting bird populations or habitats has a positive, contributory effect on ecosystem health or resilience. A unified predicate capturing positive impact on ecosystem condition improves schema consistency while remaining faithful to the causal semantics indicated by the descriptions and qualifiers.
args.remark: Chosen as a domain-specific but reusable predicate for positive impacts on ecosystem health/resilience.

args.justification: Each relation links a conservation-related subject (bird populations or habitats) to an ecosystem condition attribute (health or resilience), expressing how the subject affects ecosystem condition. Grouping them under an ecosystem_condition_relation class captures this shared thematic focus.

The descriptions and qualifiers (e.g., 'contributes to', 'is crucial for; ensuring') indicate that the subjects causally support or enhance the ecosystem attributes, not merely co-occur. This is best modeled as a causal impact relation rather than simple association.
